Signature; Date; Inscription

Dated and inscribed on mount, LC, in black ink: [1931 M.8 \'C. - C. = Fisch.\']
on mount LL in pencil: [S.cl]

\"S.cl,\" stands for \"Sonderclasse,\" or \"special class.\" They were put there by Klee to identify works that he especially liked.
medium: Watercolor and ink on gesso ground on paper
provenance: Werner Allenbach, Bern (until 1961); (Berggruen & Cie, Paris; 1961-67); (Galerie Europe, Paris; from 1967); Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler (by 1971-1977; gave to MIA, 1977).
text: With the title C.-C.=Fish, Klee describes the simple act of creation at the heart of this work. According to the equation, he subtracted one C from another C to create the form of a fish; the intersection of the two opposing Cs defines the tail fin. The fish's eye and lateral fin appear through the seemingly random course of a freely-drawn line. As in all of his work, Klee emphasizes the basic elements of form and shape that make up a work of art. Through a simple equation, he reminds us that the process of art making is the most important part of a picture. The notation "S.cl" on the mount of the drawing means "Sonderclasse," or "special class." It was inscribed by Klee to identify those works he especially liked.
title: C. - C. = Fisch
